page.title: 10WETHERBY RACECOURSE
page.content: This is a National Hunt course. Horses were placed in the stables and guarded there. Then they were paraded. Next we saw people judging the horses before, perhaps, placing a bet with either the Tote or one of the many bookmakers' stalls gathered in front of the main stand. The 'bookies' came from various places, including other racecourse towns e.g. York. One from Hamilton came{"because in Scotland {there are 3 p's porridge, potatoes & {poverty".}Changing odds in the betting were sent between 'bookies' in special semaphore by someone called a 'Tick-Tack' man. It was most obvious that the horses tipped in the popular press came nowhere! There were no plans for increasing the range of attractions, although an increase in popularity and success was hoped for.
